questions.text: A 3-year-old child with short bowel syndrome presents with severe malabsorption. Which surgical procedure involves stapling a dilated bowel into V shapes on alternating sides, decreasing the width and increasing the bowel length to improve nutrient absorption?

A 6-year-old child with a history of extensive small bowel resection due to necrotizing enterocolitis is diagnosed with short bowel syndrome. Which among the following surgical procedures can help increase the bowel length and potentially reduce the dependency on parenteral nutrition?

A 45-year-old male presents with severe malnutrition and liver dysfunction even after subclavian parenteral nutrition for extensive small bowel resection. Which of the following is the most definitive treatment for his condition?

A 52-year-old male patient who underwent extensive resection of the small intestine for Crohn’s disease presents with persistent diarrhea and worsening malnutrition. Despite following a strict dietary regimen, he is unable to maintain adequate nutritional status or fluid balance without intravenous support. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

A 60-year-old woman with a history of extensive small bowel resection presents with persistent diarrhea, significant weight loss, and signs of malnutrition. She is unable to maintain adequate fluid and nutritional balance despite dietary modifications. what condition is she most likely experiencing?
A 55-year-old patient with radiation enteritis undergoes bowel resection and develops short bowel syndrome. Which statement about bowel function is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The jejunum compensates well for the loss of the ileum.

options.label: B
options.text: The ileum can compensate for a resected jejunum due to better absorption.

options.label: C
options.text: Short bowel syndrome is less severe with distal bowel loss.

options.label: D
options.text: The ileum’s compensation is reduced due to looser junctions.

questions.correct_answer: B. The ileum can compensate for a resected jejunum due to better absorption.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath, and swelling in his legs. He has had a history of intermittent facial flushing and diarrhea for the past several years. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following diagnostic steps is most appropriate to establish a definitive diagnosis of abdominal TB in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Biopsy of the involved site with mycobacterial culture and nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)

questions.correct_answer: D. Biopsy of the involved site with mycobacterial culture and nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Method

Details

Definitive Diagnosis (Option D)

M. tuberculosis Demonstration:

  • Peritoneal fluid (in ascites)
  • Biopsy specimen (peritoneum, intestine, liver)
  • Mycobacterial culture and/or NAAT:
  • Histopathology: The presence of caseating granulomas suggests TB but is not pathognomonic

Radiographic Imaging

CT with Enterography Protocol: (Option B ruled out)

Preferred for cross-sectional evaluation

  • Intestinal TB: Concentric mural thickening in the ileocecal region, lymphadenopathy with hypodense centers
  • Peritoneal TB: Ascites, lymph nodes, mesentery and omental thickening, peritoneal thickening
  • Hepatic TB:
    • Miliary disease: Multiple low-density micronodules throughout the liver
    • Local disease: Large solitary nodule or 2-3 low-density nodules with calcification and peripheral enhancement

Ultrasound:

Detects lymphadenopathy, ascites, peritoneal thickening, omental thickening, bowel wall thickening

Other Imaging:

  • Small bowel follow-through/barium enema: Mucosal ulcerations, strictures, deformed cecum, incompetent ileocecal valve
  • Plain radiography: Air fluid levels, dilated small bowel loops, hepatic calcifications
  • Chest radiography: For suspected abdominal TB

Ascitic Fluid Analysis

Routine Tests:

  • Cell count and differential, albumin and protein concentration, Gram stain

TB-specific Tests:

  • ADA level (Option C ruled out), AFB smear, mycobacterial culture, NAAT for M. tuberculosis (if available)

Typical Findings:

  • Lymphocytic ascites with SAAG <1.1 g/dL in noncirrhotic patients (Option A ruled out)
  • Straw-colored ascites
  • leukocyte count 150-4000 cells/mm³
  • relative lymphocytic pleocytosis
  • Protein content >3.0 g/dL

The sensitivity of AFB smear and mycobacterial culture is low

Biopsy Specimens

  
  • Laparoscopy: Visualization of peritoneum, peritoneal biopsy
  • Endoscopy: Biopsies in the setting of intestinal involvement
  • Radiographic-guided interventions
  • Histopathology:
    • Caseating granulomas and positive acid-fast stain in fewer than 33% of cases
    • Confluent granulomas, granulomas >400 micrometres, >5 granulomas in one segment, and submucosal granulomas suggest TB enteritis

Additional Diagnostic Tools
  • Tuberculin skin test/interferon-gamma release assay: Positive in abdominal TB but limited value (does not differentiate active disease from latent infection)
  • Stool PCR: Useful adjunctive tool for diagnosing intestinal TB

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain that started 30 minutes after his last meal. He is tachycardic and hypotensive and laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis and elevated chromogranin A levels. A CT scan shows bowel wall enhancement and free fluid in the abdomen. Which of the following is the most preferred treatment?

A 48-year-old woman presents with episodes of flushing, diarrhea, and abdominal pain over the past six months. She also reports intermittent wheezing and feels her symptoms worsen after consuming certain foods. On physical examination, she exhibits a rash on her face and neck. Imaging studies reveal a tumor in the ileum of the small intestine. What is the initial investigation of choice for localisation in this patient?
What is the most peculiar feature of gastric carcinoid tumor?

options.label: D
options.text: Bright red patchy flushing of skin

questions.correct_answer: D. Bright red patchy flushing of skin

questions.text: A 55 y/o male presents with flushing, diarrhea, and recurrent episodes of bronchospasm. Imaging reveals multiple masses in the ileum. Laboratory tests show elevated serotonin levels. What is the most likely type of tumor responsible for his symptoms?
Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common small bowel tumor in adults is carcinoid tumor.

options.label: B
options.text: The most common small bowel tumor in children is a neuroendocrine tumor.

options.label: C
options.text: The most common primary malignant small bowel tumor is adenocarcinoma.

options.label: D
options.text: The most common small bowel tumor in adults is lymphoma.

questions.correct_answer: C. The most common primary malignant small bowel tumor is adenocarcinoma.
questions.explanation:
Classification of Small Bowel Tumors

Benign Tumors
  • Adenomas: Most common benign SBT is adenoma
  • Lipomas
  • Haemangiomas
  • Neurogenic tumors

Malignant Tumors

Adenocarcinoma (Option C)
  • Found more often in the jejunum than the ileum.
  • Associated with Crohn's disease, coeliac disease, FAP, HNPCC, and Peutz–Jeghers syndrome.
  • The most common primary malignant SBT is: Adenocarcinoma > Carcinoid>Lymphoma and (Option A ruled out)

Neuroendocrine Tumors (NETs)

Arise from Kulchitsky cells, small primary tumor with potential for significant lymph node metastases, up to one-third involve multiple tumors.

Lymphomas
  • Can be primary or secondary to systemic lymphoma, increased incidence in patients with Crohn's disease and immunodeficiency syndromes.
  • The most common SBT in children is Lymphoma. (Option B and D ruled out)

Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs)
  • Mesenchymal tumors, are difficult to classify as benign or malignant, with larger size and high c-kit (CD117) staining associated with malignancy. Found throughout the gut, most commonly in the stomach.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male presents with chronic abdominal discomfort and bloating. Imaging shows multiple jejunal diverticula. The physician suspects these are due to increased intraluminal pressure. What is the most likely etiology of these diverticula?

options.label: A
options.text: Congenital origin due to incomplete recanalization of the duodenum

options.label: B
options.text: Acquired origin due to smooth muscle motor dysfunction

options.label: D
options.text: Protrusion of the entire intestinal wall layers

questions.correct_answer: B. Acquired origin due to smooth muscle motor dysfunction

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with gastrointestinal tuberculosis presents with abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. Imaging studies reveal a long, narrow filling defect in the terminal ileum. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Ulcerative tuberculosis with subacute obstruction and perforation

options.label: B
options.text: Crohn’s disease with a narrowed segment and proximal distension

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperplastic tuberculosis with a filling defect in the terminal ileum and lymphadenopathy

options.label: D
options.text: Appendicitis with mass in the right iliac fossa

questions.correct_answer: C. Hyperplastic tuberculosis with a filling defect in the terminal ileum and lymphadenopathy
questions.explanation:
Feature

Ulcerative Tuberculosis

(Option A ruled out)

Hyperplastic Tuberculosis

(Option C)

Symptoms
  • Diarrhea
  • Weight loss
  • Abdominal pain
  • Intermittent diarrhea

Complications/Consequences
  • Subacute obstruction
  • Perforation
  • Fistula formation
  • Incomplete ileal obstruction
  • Stasis
  • Bacterial overgrowth
  • Steatorrhea
  • Anemia
  • Weight loss

Diagnostic Findings
  • Barium follow-through/CT: Absence of contrast filling in the distal ileum, caecum, and ascending colon due to narrowing of an ulcerated segment
  • Physical exam: Mass in right iliac fossa
  • Barium follow-through/small bowel enema: Long, narrow filling defect in terminal ileum
  • CT scan: Narrowed segment with proximal distension and lymphadenopathy

questions.text: A patient with pulmonary tuberculosis is diagnosed with ulcers in the terminal ileum. Which form of gastrointestinal tuberculosis is characterized by this presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperplastic tuberculosis with intestinal wall thickening.

options.label: B
options.text: Ulcerative tuberculosis with transverse ulcers and serosal thickening.

options.label: C
options.text: Crohn’s disease with abscesses and fistulas.

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperplastic tuberculosis with abscesses and fistulas.

questions.correct_answer: B. Ulcerative tuberculosis with transverse ulcers and serosal thickening.
questions.explanation:
Variant

Description

Ulcerative Tuberculosis (Option B)
  • Caused by ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, often in those with pulmonary TB.
  • Results in multiple transverse ulcers, primarily in the terminal ileum.
  • Leads to thickening and inflammation of the serosa, covered in tubercles.

Hyperplastic Tuberculosis

(Option A ruled out)
  • Develops in individuals with high resistance to Mycobacterium tuberculosis who ingest the bacteria.
  • Commonly affects the ileocaecal region and distal ileum.
  • Causes chronic inflammation in lymphoid follicles, thickening of the intestinal wall, and narrowing of the lumen.
  • Less likely to cause abscesses and fistulas, and often presents with regional lymph node involvement with potential caseation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with symptoms of abdominal pain and weight loss. He has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis. On examination, his abdomen is tender in the right iliac fossa. A barium follow-through study reveals a long, narrow filling defect in the terminal ileum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ulcerative Tuberculosis

Hyperplastic Tuberculosis (Option A)

 

Cause

Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis; ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis by individuals with high resistance.

Affected Area

Terminal ileum

The ileocaecal region; can also affect the distal ileum

Characteristics
  • Multiple transverse ulcers.
  • Thickened and inflamed serosa with tubercles.

 
  • Chronic inflammation in lymphoid follicles.
  • Thickening of the intestinal wall and lumen narrowing.
  • Rare abscess and fistula formation.
  • Early involvement of regional lymph nodes, which may caseate

Barium follow-through and CT

No filling defect due to narrowing of ulcerated segment
  • Long narrow filling defect
  • CT shows a narrowed segment with proximal distension

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with a history of weight loss presents with intermittent abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Imaging shows compression of the third portion of the duodenum between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery. Conservative dietary management has failed. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Treatment Type

Description

Notes

Strong Procedure

Duodenum is mobilized by dividing the ligament of Treitz. Once the duodenal jejunal junction is mobilized, the duodenum is positioned to the right of the superior mesenteric artery

No risk of anastomotic leak.

Laparoscopic Duodenojejunostomy (Option A)

Optimal definitive treatment; involves creating a bypass from the duodenum to the jejunum.

Minimally invasive, reduced recovery times and lower complication rates compared to open surgery.

Open Surgical Procedures (Option B & D ruled out)

Employed when laparoscopic methods are not feasible or have failed.

Includes duodenojejunostomy or other bypass surgeries; higher morbidity.

Other Interventions

Conservative management (dietary modifications, nutritional support) is attempted first but often fails. (Option C ruled out)

Surgical intervention is necessary for severe obstruction or significant weight loss.

questions.text: A 30 y/o male with a history of rapid weight loss presents with severe postprandial abdominal pain and vomiting. The physician suspects Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) syndrome. Which imaging technique is most suitable for visualizing the compression of the duodenum by the SMA and accurately measuring the aortomesenteric angle?
Which of the following is NOT TRUE regarding superior mesenteric artery syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Early satiety and postprandial epigastric pain are present.

options.label: B
options.text: The knee to the chest or left lateral decubitus position alleviates symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: Presentation is always acute, needing emergency intervention.

questions.correct_answer: C. Presentation is always acute, needing emergency intervention.

questions.text: Which part of the duodenum is compressed in superior mesenteric artery syndrome?

A 6-year-old boy is diagnosed with symptomatic Meckel's diverticulum after presenting with painless rectal bleeding. The diverticulum is found to be inflamed and with ulcers in the base. Which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Resection of small bowel with diverticulum.

questions.correct_answer: B. Resection of small bowel with diverticulum.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with intermittent episodes of blood in his stools without pain. On examination, there are no signs of acute abdomen. Blood investigations reveal he is anemic. Which is the investigation of choice in this case for Meckel's diverticulum?

A 2-year-old boy presents with painless rectal bleeding. CT scans show a diverticulum 2 inches long located around 2 feet proximal to the ileocaecal valve. A Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan shows an area of increased uptake in the right lower quadrant. What is the most likely type of ectopic mucosal tissue found in the diverticulum that can explain these findings?
Which of the following characteristics is true regarding Meckel's diverticulum?

options.label: A
options.text: Located approximately 30 cm from the ileocecal valve.

options.label: B
options.text: Always lined with ectopic pancreatic tissue

options.label: C
options.text: Arises from the mesenteric border of the ileum.

options.label: D
options.text: Contains all the layers of the bowel wall.

questions.correct_answer: D. Contains all the layers of the bowel wall.
